pageData.text: Rivers and streams are highly effective agents in erosion, carving, and shaping the surface of the Earth as they flow over it, creating many different topographic features. During this lab, students will examine topographic maps to explore why streams behave uniquely and how they can produce very different landscapes. Historical hydrologic data will also be used to determine the flooding hazards of a stream.

pageData.text: Climate change is not only causing sea levels to rise, but also changes to the salinity of the ocean. As more glaciers and sea ice melts, more fresh water enters the oceans and lowers the salinity. In some regions, drought is causing increased levels of evaporation, and salinity is increasing. The salinity of seawater is important and even small changes in it can have huge impacts on the water cycle and ocean circulation<sup className=bodySupscript>1</sup>. These changes are leading to increased precipitation in some regions, while others are experiencing extreme drought.

Decreased precipitation can affect the salinity of coastal waters. A balance between freshwater and saltwater is required for a healthy estuary. Droughts reduce freshwater input into tidal rivers and bays, which raises salinity in estuaries. This allows for saltwater to mix further upstream. This increases the salinity in brackish water environments and threatens to degrade the ecosystem's health. The increase in salinity not only threatens the plants and animals that have adapted to live in brackish waters, but it can penetrate the groundwater and threaten drinking water and infrastructure.

pageData.text: Water covers approximately 70% of the Earthâ€™s surface and is stored in oceans, glaciers, ice sheets, rivers and lakes, the atmosphere, and even in our bodies. Itâ€™s constantly changing into its various forms as a solid, liquid, or gas in the <button class='glossary-text'>hydrologic (water) cycle</button> (Figure 1). This cycle is balanced as the Earthâ€™s water moves from precipitation to infiltration and runoff to evapotranspiration.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Drainage basins</button>/<button class='glossary-text'>watersheds</button> are areas where water collects in a particular region. <button class='glossary-text'>Drainage networks</button> are regions of land that are formed by rivers and streams where minerals cannot contain organic carbon, which is a carbon atom bound to at least one hydrogen atom. <button class='glossary-text'>Dendritic networks</button> are river systems (with contributing rivers joining a main river) that resemble branches stemming off a tree (Figure 2). This is because the water flows over a slight slope and the ground is relatively uniform in these regions.

These cracks break up the ground, and water flows into these spots in straight line segments that have right angle bends. At those bends, the bodies of water tend to connect and flow into these spaces along the joints.

pageData.text: When water runs down the side of steep slopes that lie beside each other but are not touching, geologists refer to these <button class='glossary-text'>drainage networks</button> as <button class='glossary-text'>parallel networks</button> (Figure 5).

A <button class='glossary-text'>drainage divide</button> is a very high ridge that keeps bodies of water separated. A <button class='glossary-text'>continental divide</button> separates the drainage from bodies of water into separate oceans.

pageData.subTitle: Stream Erosion
pageData.text: Gravity has a large effect on the ways streams can change the landscape. When water erodes its environment slowly, it is known as <button class='glossary-text'>laminar flow</button>. Stream flow, however, is usually fast, which is known as <button class='glossary-text'>turbulent flow</button>. How well a stream can erode its environment is dependent on the velocity, volume, and sediment composition. Most erosion will occur with large volumes of water moving extremely fast, as in the case of flooding.

<button class='glossary-text'>Scouring </button> is the process of running water to remove loose pieces of rock and other substances. Sometimes the water is flowing fast enough to remove an attached rock. This phenomenon is known as <button class='glossary-text'>breaking and lifting</button>. Sandy water can also be a catalyst for erosion. <button class='glossary-text'>Abrasion</button> occurs when sand in the water acts as sandpaper and smooths out its surroundings. <button class='glossary-text'>Dissolution</button> is the process of dissolving minerals in a stream. These minerals can be carried along with the water.

The minerals dissolved in a stream become a part of a <button class='glossary-text'>dissolved load</button>. Streams that can carry small particles are said to have a low competence, whereas streams that carry larger pieces are said to have a high competence.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Drainage in a parallel network on the side of a steep slope
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Drainage in a parallel network on the side of a steep slope

pageData.text: Competence is based on the flow; a stream with a <button class='glossary-text'>turbulent flow</button> will have a higher competence than a stream with a <button class='glossary-text'>laminar flow</button>. When referring to the number of particles a stream can carry (capacity), competence and discharge are the main factors.

The muddy appearance in a river is generally the bulk majority of the . Very small solids, like clay and silt, are transported in the suspended load. During a flood, the suspended load increases dramatically and may include larger particles, such as sand. Larger pieces of rock and debris are known to be a part of the . The bed load is usually the smallest portion of the sediment and, most of the time, will not exceed 10% of the load.

pageData.subTitle: Depositional Processes
pageData.text: In general, larger items deposit in the stream early while many smaller items travel farther with the movement of the water. <button class='glossary-text'>Alluvium</button> is the name for sediment that has accumulated along a streambed. When alluvium forms piles on the side of the stream, it is referred to as forming <button class='glossary-text'>bars</button>, which typically emerge along the sides of a meandering river. A <button class='glossary-text'>delta</button> is created from the sediment that collects as water is dumped out into a body of water, such as into an ocean or a lake.

pageData.subTitle: Depositional Landforms
pageData.text: Sometimes streams can carve a deeper canal than the channel itself. This event results in <button class='glossary-text'>valleys</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>canyons</button>. The main difference between a valley and a canyon is the steepness of the slope; valleys generally have gentle slopes, and canyons have steeper ones. A <button class='glossary-text'>rapid</button> is very choppy water with a rugged surface. A rapid is created when water is carried over large, clastic rock, where the channel immediately becomes smaller or the gradient alters significantly. <button class='glossary-text'>Waterfalls</button> form as a result of a stream flowing across a steep, resistant ledge of rock or when a stream becomes too steep and falls off the streambed. Waterfalls are not permanent features of the landscape, because the erosion process will eventually wear down the rock and the stream will dissipate.

Generally, when mountainous landscape drastically changes to a flat plain, the water that is channeled in from the mountain extends outward and forms an <button class='glossary-text'>alluvial fan</button> (Figure 6). Alluvial fans are common in dry regions and often occur with flash flooding. <button class='glossary-text'>Braided streams</button> have a high occurrence during flash floods. These complicated networks of many channels form when the sediment contains a substantial amount of coarse material and has variable discharge.

A meandering stream looks similar to a snake slithering because the sinuosity (curve) of the stream is greater than streams without meanders. Erosion actively occurs in a meandering riverâ€™s loops, which are called . In some instances, erosion occurs deep within the meander and forms cutoff areas (or crescent-shaped lakes) known as (circled in Figure 8). Sediment that accumulates next to the river on low-laying ground is known as a . , which contain the banks of rivers, are formed over time as sediment is deposited on the sides of the stream.

pageData.text: In Activity 3, you will analyze flood data to determine the recurrence interval for floods and calculate the probability of a flood occurring in a given period.

typeBefore.text: Floods often occur with excessive precipitation that results in streams and rivers overflowing onto dry land. Geologists are able to predict when floods may occur based on previous data. In this activity, you will analyze data regarding flood recurrence. Table 1 shows peak discharge and calculated recurrence intervals for a particular river from 1944â€“1986.The recurrence interval (RI) can be seen in Table 1 and is calculated using this formula: RI = (N + 1)/rank, where N = number of years that river is at peak discharge and rank = ranked order of the flood starting with the largest discharge.For this river, from 1944â€“1986, N = 43 years. (Donâ€™t forget to include the first year in this calculation as well.)Here is an example of how the RIs were calculated for the first two ranked floods:RI = (N + 1)/rank; RI = (43 + 1)/1; RI = 44RI = (N + 1)/rank; RI = (43 + 1)/2; RI = 22

pageData.text: Over the next 4 years (1987â€“1990), additional measurements were taken at the river. Calculate the recurrence interval (RI) for the next 2 ranked floods by using the same formula for recurrence interval (RI = [N + 1]/rank) used in Table 1. (Donâ€™t forget to increase N by 4 years due to the 4-year addition to the current N of 43 of the river.) Record the recurrence intervals in Data Table 1.

Either using graph paper or graphing software (i.e., MicrosoftÂ® ExcelÂ® or Google Sheetsâ„¢), plot discharge as the dependent variable (y-axis) and the recurrence interval (RI) as the independent variable (x-axis). For RI values of 11 or greater, draw a straight line through the points.

A map of the procedural workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will mix food coloring and water. In activity 1, you will sculpt a landform from clay and place it into a container. Then, you will mark the north side of the landform. Next, you will trace the landform outline onto transparency paper. Then, you will add 0.5 cm of colored water to the container. Next, you will trace a new outline of the landform at the water level. You will repeat this until you have traced all levels of the landform. Then, you will tape the transparency to a white piece of paper and use a window or light source to trace the topographical map onto the white piece of paper. Finally, you will clean the transparency and proceed to activity 2.

A map of the procedural workflow for activities 2-3 of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, you will number your plastic containers and cut out the topographical map. Then, you will place the map onto the top of the upside-down container and place the next container on top of the map. Next, you will trace the outermost contour line onto the container. Then, you will remove the traced container and place the next container on top of the map. Next, you will trace the next contour line onto the container. You will do this until you have traced all of the contour lines onto containers. Then, you will stack the traced containers in order and photograph the 3-D terrain model you have created. In activity 3, you will calculate the recurrence interval for flood data. Then, you will graph discharge versus recurrence interval. Finally, you will calculate the probability of a flood recurring for the given intervals.

data.title: Abrasion
data.content: Occurs when sand in the water acts as sandpaper and smooths out its surroundings

data.title: Alluvial fan
data.content: A triangle-shaped deposit of gravel, sand, and even smaller pieces of sediment such as silt, found at the base of a mountainous landscape

data.title: Alluvium
data.content: Sediment that has accumulated along a streambed

data.title: Bar
data.content: An alluvium deposit along on the side of a stream or river

data.title: Bed load
data.content: The totality of larger pieces of rock and debris suspended in the water

data.title: Braided stream
data.content: A stream consisting of multiple small, shallow channels that divide and recombine numerous times forming a pattern resembling the strands of a braid

data.title: Breaking and lifting
data.content: Occurs when scouring flow is fast enough to remove an attached rock

data.title: Canyon
data.content: A canal created by the erosion from streams or rivers, with steeper slopes than a valley

data.title: Continental divide
data.content: Separates drainage from bodies of water into separate oceans

data.title: Cut bank
data.content: An area of erosion caused by a meandering stream in areas of higher stream velocity

data.title: Delta
data.content: An accumulation of sediment that is collected as water from a stream or river is dumped out into a larger body of water

data.title: Dendritic network
data.content: A river system that resembles branches stemming off a tree

data.title: Dissolution
data.content: The process of dissolving minerals in a stream

data.title: Dissolved load
data.content: The totality of dissolved minerals in a stream

data.title: Drainage basin
data.content: An area of land which all precipitation flows to a single stream or set of streams

data.title: Drainage divide
data.content: A very high ridge that keeps bodies separated

data.title: Drainage network
data.content: A region of land that is formed by rivers and streams where minerals cannot contain organic carbon

data.title: Floodplain
data.content: Sediment that accumulates next to the river on low-laying ground

data.title: Hydrologic cycle
data.content: The continuous movement of water throughout the surface of the Earth

data.title: Laminar flow
data.content: The flow speed of a body of water in which erosion of the environment occurs slowly

data.title: Meandering stream
data.content: A stream that winds snakelike through its valley

data.title: Natural levee
data.content: A raised section of land that forms along a riverbank or shoreline that is created when a river overflows its banks deposits sediment

data.title: Oxbow lake
data.content: A crescent-shaped lake that is formed when a meander of a river is cut off from the main channel

data.title: Parallel network
data.content: A river system where water runs down the side of steep slopes that lie beside each other but are not touching

data.title: Radial network
data.content: a river system that flows off a mountain or volcano

data.title: Rapid
data.content: Choppy water with a rugged surface created when water is carried over large, clastic rock, altering the gradient of the flow

data.title: Rectangular network
data.content: a river system that is commonly found in areas where bedrock has many cracks that break up the ground

data.title: Scouring
data.content: The process of running water removing loose pieces of rock and other substances

data.title: Sinuosity
data.content: The degree to which a river or stream moves back and forth over the terrain

data.title: Suspended load
data.content: The totality of very small particles, such as clay or silt, suspended in the water

data.title: Trellis network
data.content: A river system that is usually found in locations with poor rock structures

data.title: Turbulent flow
data.content: The flow speed of a body of water in which erosion of the environment occurs quickly

data.title: Valley
data.content: A canal created by the erosion from streams or rivers, with sides that have a more gentle slope compared to a canyon

data.title: Waterfall
data.content: A water feature formed as a result of a stream flowing across a steep, resistant ledge of rock, or when a stream becomes too steep and falls off the streambed

data.title: Watershed
data.content: An area or ridge that separates waters flowing to different rivers, basins or seas
